title: Circuits - Nonohmic resistor and nonideal battery

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A student is provided with several resistors with different known resistances, an ideal battery, a voltmeter, an ammeter, and connecting wires. The student is given an additional resistive component <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math>.(a) The student is asked to design an experimental procedure to determine whether <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> is ohmic using the equipment provided.i. Using the symbols shown, draw a diagram of a circuit that the student could use to determine whether <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> is ohmic, including the appropriate placement of the measurement devices.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A student is provided with several resistors with different known resistances, an ideal battery, a voltmeter, an ammeter, and connecting wires. The student is given an additional resistive component <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math>.(a) The student is asked to design an experimental procedure to determine whether <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> is ohmic using the equipment provided.i. Using the symbols shown, draw a diagram of a circuit that the student could use to determine whether <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> is ohmic, including the appropriate placement of the measurement devices.

ii. Referring to your diagram, describe the overall procedure, providing enough detail so that students could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be graphed and how that graph would be analyzed to determine whether <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> is ohmic.

In a different experiment, the student uses the same resistors of known resistance, a battery of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math> with internal resistance <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, and an ammeter connected as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The student is asked to determine the internal resistance <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> of the battery. For each value of the resistance <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> of the known resistors, the student measures the current in the ammeter. The student’s data are represented in the following table.<math alttext="uppercase R, in ohms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="I, in milliamps" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>mA</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math><math alttext="58" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>58</mn></math><math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math><math alttext="44" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>44</mn></math><math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math><math alttext="31" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>31</mn></math><math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn></math><math alttext="28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>28</mn></math><math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn></math><math alttext="22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>22</mn></math><math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math><math alttext="19" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>19</mn></math>(c)i. Indicate two quantities that could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to determine the internal resistance <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> of the battery. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.__________Vertical Axis __________Horizontal Axis
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the graph provided. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units as appropriate.
iii. Draw a best-fit line to the data graphed in part (c)(ii).
(d) Using the best-fit line, calculate the internal resistance of the battery.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
